meaning_mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>attach</radical>.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>valley</radical>.

You have a leaf, a mouth, and an eye. Those are all things you'll find on a <radical>face</radical>! Wait, you don't have a leaf growing out of your face? Huh... well just imagine you have a normal human face with a leaf on there somewhere, ya weirdo.

This radical is made up of samurai and beans. Samurai used to put beans in <radical>drum</radical>s so they could tap and shake them to make noise. Can you imagine shaking and tapping this drum radical?

This radical has a figure reaching out both hands at you with some dirt on his head. This is a <radical>zombie</radical>, and he must have just recently dug himself out of the grave by the looks of it.
You examine the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>zombie</radical> and find a small <kanji>garden</kanji> in there. There are even benches... it looks like a <kanji>park</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You look closer at the <kanji>garden</kanji> and suddenly everything <reading>en</reading>ds (えん).

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> is out, you can see two <radical>Wolverine</radical>s and a <radical>turkey</radical> playing together, but only on a certain <kanji>weekday</kanji>. Which <kanji>day of the week</kanji> is it? I'll never tell you. It could be Sunday. It could be Monday. It could be any day of the week.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you know how to figure out what <kanji>day of the week</kanji> it is, you can start making <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). It can take up to 24 hours to make yogurt. Knowing which weekday it is at any given moment means you can perfect your yogurt-making schedule.

meaning_mnemonic: Why would you try to take a <radical>brush</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical>? It's almost too obvious, because you want to <kanji>write</kanji> something down.
reading_mnemonic: What did you <kanji>write</kanji> about? You were writing about this amazing circus <reading>show</reading> (しょ) you just watched on the sun. You didn't expect there to be any shows here, but turns out you were wrong!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>scooter</radical> with a <radical>zombie</radical> on it, going really <kanji>far</kanji> away. Someone tied that zombie to the scooter and now it's far off in the distance, groaning and growling.
reading_mnemonic: The zombie goes so <kanji>far</kanji>, that its life <reading>en</reading>ds (えん). Zombies need to eat to live (it's really all they need), but they go so far on their scooter trip, that they just give up and end it all.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>gate</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>gates</kanji> are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You want to pass through this <kanji>gate</kanji> but it’s guarded by… a <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん)!

meaning_mnemonic: A psychic <radical>leader</radical> kneels to the <radical>ground</radical>, picks up a <radical>thread</radical>, and instantly makes a <kanji>connection</kanji> with the person that it came from. This leader is very powerful, so even a thread is enough for them to make a psychic connection with the person who was wearing it.
reading_mnemonic: As you develop this psychic <kanji>connection</kanji> with the owner of the thread, you can tell that they're currently eating a <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>products</radical> radical and the <kanji>product</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Productive!
reading_mnemonic: As you try to sell these <kanji>product</kanji>s, you finally get a buyer. It's a <reading>Hin</reading>du (ひん) person. She walks in and buys your products on the spot!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>roof</radical> needs <radical>measurement</radical>s done every year to make sure it will <kanji>protect</kanji> you properly.
reading_mnemonic: If the measurements are off, and your roof doesn't <kanji>protect</kanji> you, then you get to <reading>sue</reading> (す)! If you're still alive, that is.

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>lid</radical> on something <radical>spicy</radical> and you'll cook up pure <kanji>happiness</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Out of spicy foods you made pure <kanji>happiness</kanji>. You give it to your sad friend <reading>こう</reading>いち, who waits at the table.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>prison</radical> where you once kept <radical>Wolverine</radical>, you find a beating <radical>heart</radical>. You don't understand how it's still going, but you know you need to <kanji>hurry</kanji> up and do something, or it might stop all of a <kanji>sudden</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You start to overheat as you <kanji>hurry</kanji> around, so you grab a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう) to cool you down. The high water content re-hydrates you and lets you continue hurrying to help save this heart.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>pope</radical> stays fixated on the <radical>ground</radical>, staring at <radical>fins</radical>, he's going to lose touch with <kanji>reality</kanji>. He should be focusing on his popish duties, but instead he's looking at the fish fins he dropped, and now can't eat because they're dirty. Silly pope. You can't let this one thing get you down. You have other things to do.
reading_mnemonic: You're doing your best to bring the pope back to <kanji>reality</kanji> when he snaps and kicks you in the <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Oww! What the heck, pope! But he's already back staring at the fins and your shin is throbbing where he kicked it.

meaning_mnemonic: With the <radical>bamboo</radical> from that <radical>tree</radical>, your trained <radical>eye</radical> can tell it'll make an excellent <kanji>box</kanji>. Boxes made from bamboo trees are very sturdy and fashionable. You have an eye for fashion as well, you see.
reading_mnemonic: Now you can use that <kanji>box</kanji> to store all your <reading>ha</reading>rd<reading>co</reading>re (はこ) punk vinyl records. You're a real connoisseur, so you know that hardcore music should only ever be kept in bamboo boxes.

meaning_mnemonic: You offer <radical>flowers</radical> to your <radical>leader</radical> and compliment them on their <radical>lip ring</radical>. You think that by doing this they might carry your <kanji>luggage</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Unconvinced by your flattery, the leader refuses to carry your <kanji>luggage</kanji>, so you get on your <reading>knee</reading>s (に) and beg them to carry it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>face</radical> radical and the <kanji>face</kanji> kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the <kanji>surface</kanji> kind of face too!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>face</kanji> you're looking at, that has a lot of <kanji>surface</kanji> area, belongs to <reading>men</reading> (めん). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row.

meaning_mnemonic: If you play <radical>music</radical> with your <radical>fins</radical>, one <kanji>rule</kanji> is that you must be a fish. You can’t play music using fish fins that don’t belong to you. That’s the rule. And it’s also rude.
reading_mnemonic: There’s also a <kanji>rule</kanji> in place to limit the amount of fish fin musicians. No more than <reading>ten</reading> (てん) are allowed to gather and play their music together. That’s the rule. No more than ten.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> <radical>attach</radical>ing your entire country is the <kanji>government</kanji>. They loom over you all and try to keep you all organized and together under their control.
reading_mnemonic: Try to get out from under this <kanji>government</kanji> canopy and you'll be labeled a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). Unless... you can fool them!

meaning_mnemonic:
After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, use this <radical>machine</radical> to <kanji>cure</kanji> the people and the country from the damage. <kanji>Heal</kanji>ing machines are all over Japan just in case a tsunami does way more damage than they can handle. 

Oh, and whoever cures and heals the most people will be able to <kanji>rule</kanji> over them once everything starts going back to normal. So keep that in mind, kay?
reading_mnemonic:
Alternative ways to <kanji>cure</kanji> yourself after a tsunami are either praying to <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) or eating your weight in <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). I'm not sure if I have enough cheese for all the people that got hit though... Hmm, do you have cheese?

Before you make your decision, remember that whoever cures you will be able to <kanji>reign</kanji> over you and your people. So do you want to be led by Jesus or by some cheese? The choice is yours.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>valley</radical>, filling it up with water. Lucky for you, you're a giant, so you just lay down in the valley and use it to <kanji>bathe</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You know what would make the <kanji>bath</kanji>ing experience even better? If you had some egg <reading>yolk</reading>s (よく) to eat. Just crack those yolks into the water you bathe in, and it'll cook to perfection. Yum!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Bamboo</radical> <radical>heaven</radical> is a place for <kanji>laugh</kanji>ing. Bamboo is a very jolly plant, and they love to laugh. Even after death in bamboo heaven, the bamboo continue to laugh joyfully. Bamboo heaven is truly a place of laughter.
reading_mnemonic: There’s actually a war a goin’ on up in that there bamboo heaven, y’know? Ye might not have heard of it with all that there <kanji>laugh</kanji>in’ a goin’ on, but there definitely be a <reading>war a</reading> (わら) goin’ on up in bamboo heaven, y’hear? The bamboo are scared so that’s why they be laughin’ so much. They nervous.

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <radical>tongue</radical> becomes too <radical>spicy</radical> for you to bear, it’s time to <kanji>quit</kanji> the jalapeño eating contest. You’ve been eating them for three hours now and the spiciness from the peppers is really burning your tongue. Throw in the towel, it’s time to quit the contest.

This kanji has another meaning too:

Eating isn't the only thing that makes your <radical>tongue</radical> <radical>spicy</radical>, so do certain <kanji>word</kanji>s. Say your favorite words out loud right now. Feel them on your tongue. Words are the spicy food of language!
reading_mnemonic: Oh, you're probably wondering who won that spicy food contest after you <kanji>quit</kanji> and became obsessed with <kanji>word</kanji>s instead. It was <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). Who did you expect? He was great with words AND never quitting when things got spicy.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>gate</radical> of <radical>horns</radical> will take you to <radical>heaven</radical>. These horns are <kanji>related</kanji> and <kanji>connected</kanji> to heaven in some way.
reading_mnemonic: They are <kanji>related</kanji> and <kanji>connected</kanji> to heaven because these are the horns that Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) made from his enemies. God said he could come into heaven if he made a gate of horns, so that's what he did.

meaning_mnemonic: If you listened in to the <radical>private</radical> lives of <radical>twenty</radical> people, all of them would have different <kanji>dialect</kanji>s and ways of <kanji>speech</kanji>. Whether they actually use these dialects with you is another story. But when they're alone, or with other people who are from the same place, their speech will be different.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to learn someone's <kanji>dialect</kanji> is to buy them a <reading>ben</reading>to (べん) from where they're from. Not only do these bento have writing in their dialect on them, but their speech will immediately shift to match. Then you'll be able to hear how they sound in their head and in private!

meaning_mnemonic: It's <radical>correct</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to focus on <kanji>politics</kanji> and the <kanji>government</kanji>. Elections are happening, in the new year politicians are being sworn in. Winter is government time!
reading_mnemonic: Everyone involved in <kanji>politics</kanji> and <kanji>government</kanji> wields a special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). If two political parties are arguing, they'll whip out their sabers and start slashing away!

meaning_mnemonic: A group of <radical>private</radical> <radical>sword</radical> guys are in your <radical>rice paddy</radical>. You must <kanji>detain</kanji> them at once! Private sword guys are people who work for private companies and use their swords on people. They're basically paid assassins. And you're going to detain them!
reading_mnemonic:
You're running out of steam and you're afraid you might not be able to <kanji>detain</kanji> all of these guys when <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter appears. He hates swords, and will only use fists because it's the honorable way to fight, so he starts helping you detain them!

He's also found a <reading>loo</reading>phole (る) in the system and you don't have to be super gentle with these guys either. So detain them as forcefully as you want. It is your rice paddy they're in, after all.

meaning_mnemonic: What I <radical>say</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> 100%! You may use it as <kanji>evidence</kanji> in this murder case.
reading_mnemonic: The officials force you to present this <kanji>evidence</kanji> in front of the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう), himself. Your knees quake, you feel like you're gonna be sick, but you try to stand up tall and tell him everything. After all, you know your <kanji>proof</kanji> is correct, so you shouldn't be so scared.

meaning_mnemonic: Going into a <radical>building</radical> made by a <radical>squid</radical> is <kanji>risky</kanji>. First of all, squids only have tentacles, no bones, and they make all of their buildings out of risky materials like kelp and sharp coral.
reading_mnemonic: "It's too <kanji>risky</kanji>, leave me!" the squid cries. "I'll save you, underwater citizen! Nothing is too risky for <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai!" The building is collapsing on the squid, the risk is so great, but Ken the samurai dives in and saves him!

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>prison</radical> on a <radical>cliff</radical> surrounded by <radical>snake</radical>s. Now that's a <kanji>dangerous</kanji> place. If you try to escape the prison you either fall to your death off the cliff or get bitten/squeezed to death by the snakes. Can you think of anything more dangerous than this? I can't.
reading_mnemonic: Lucky for you, even though you're stuck in this <kanji>dangerous</kanji> place, there is hope. There is a <reading>key</reading> (き). All dangerous prisons have a key. You just have to find and steal it so you can avoid the cliffs and snakes!

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>narwhal</radical> <radical>stick</radical>s a <radical>child</radical> with its horn then you have to admit that it <kanji>exist</kanji>s. We know some of you have been doubting narwhals and whether they're real. Well now your kid is a kabob, so do you believe they exist now? I <kanji>suppose</kanji> you do.
reading_mnemonic: Oh, and the child we had to narwhal stab to prove they <kanji>exist</kanji> - that's your <reading>son</reading> (そん). Maybe you should have listened and kept your son out of the Narwhal Danger <reading>Zone</reading> (ぞん) after we warned you about it.

meaning_mnemonic: Sticking a <radical>cross</radical> into a <radical>rice paddy</radical> to get its <radical>measurement</radical>s is your <kanji>specialty</kanji>. Most people get really confused when they have to measure their rice paddies, but that's where you come in. You plant a cross right in the middle, look down it from one end to the other, and voila! You know the measurements immediately. That's why it's your specialty!
reading_mnemonic: Hearing of your amazing <kanji>specialty</kanji> and cross measurement abilities, a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) from a far off land recruits you for a job. The centaur’s father has just passed away and the centaur wants you to measure the rice paddies that have been left to him.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets in your <radical>eye</radical>, I <kanji>dare</kanji> you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
reading_mnemonic: After you’ve blinded yourself from the <kanji>dare</kanji> of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>forehead</radical> <radical>table</radical> is completely <kanji>superfluous</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The only person you know with a <kanji>superfluous</kanji> forehead table is <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the ten foot tall, simple farmhand.

meaning_mnemonic: If there's something about a <radical>building</radical> that people are <radical>anti</radical> towards, it's usually the <kanji>heights</kanji> aspect. Another thing would be if it's on a big <kanji>slope</kanji>. No one likes that kind of building.
reading_mnemonic: Another person you know who's afraid of <kanji>heights</kanji> is <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. Now wait, you protest, he flies a space ship! You're right, but only because he doesn't like to walk all the way up high buildings, it freaks him out. He flies up instead so he doesn't have to think about heights.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hat</radical> comes to a <radical>stop</radical>, thinking of a <kanji>plan</kanji>. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>plan</kanji> that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the <reading>key</reading> (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!

examples.en: This is an outpatient clinic doctor.
examples.ja: こちらは、外来クリニックの先生です。

examples.en: Mongoose is a designated invasive species, right?
examples.ja: マングースって特定外来生物でしょ？

examples.en: "Konpeitō" is a loanword, you know. It comes from the Portuguese word "confeito."
examples.ja: コンペイトウは外来語ですよ。ポルトガル語の「confeito」から来てるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
From <kanji>foreign</kanji> lands, you have <kanji>come</kanji> to this hospital. That makes you an <vocabulary>outpatient</vocabulary>. 

外来 describes something or someone that comes from elsewhere. You’ll see it most often in hospitals, where it means outpatient, but it’s also used in formal contexts to talk about <vocabulary>foreign</vocabulary> species or <vocabulary>imported</vocabulary> words.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The owner of this hotel is unknown.
examples.ja: このホテルは、オーナーが不明です。

examples.en: The day of birth is unknown.
examples.ja: 生まれた日は不明です。

examples.en: It's uncertain where my brother is now.
examples.ja: 私の兄は今どこにいるか不明なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When it's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji>, you can't see what's around you. In the dark, everything feels <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>unclear</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>uncertain</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 明 (めい) with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Everything feels particularly <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>unclear</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>uncertain</vocabulary> in <reading>May</reading> (めい) because May is when you suddenly realize you still don't know what you're doing this year — your plans are as foggy as morning mist. You sigh, "めい-be next month I'll have it together."

examples.en: Can I get to the Pacific Ocean from here?
examples.ja: ここから太平洋まで車で行けますか？

examples.en: After all, fish from the Pacific Ocean taste good.
examples.ja: 太平洋の魚はやっぱり味が良いんだよな。

examples.en: The Pacific Ocean is shiny and beautiful.
examples.ja: 太平洋の海はキラキラしてて綺麗ですね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>peace</kanji> <kanji>ocean</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Pacific Ocean</vocabulary>. The Japanese language thinks this ocean is peaceful, just like English does (the word 太平 actually means "peace").

Note that we're using the alternative meaning of 洋 here! If you didn't learn that with the kanji, just imagine that to get to Western-style places you need to cross the ocean from Japan.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've seen the たい reading for 太 in 太陽, but here's a mnemonic refresher for it just in case:

When you cross the <vocabulary>Pacific Ocean</vocabulary>, you must wear a <reading>tie</reading> (たい). Your tie is uncomfortably tight as you watch the Pacific slide by under you. But you want to look your best on this momentous journey, don't you? Doesn't matter if you're going by boat or plane, you wear a tie when you cross the Pacific.

examples.en: It is important to review the plan once a year.
examples.ja: 一年に一回、プランを見直すことが大切です。

examples.en: This time was a chance to reassess my weaknesses.
examples.ja: 今回は自分の弱点を見直すチャンスになりました。

examples.en: At university, I want to learn literature and reevaluate writers from the Heian period.
examples.ja: 大学では文学を学び、平安時代の作家を見直したいと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the word 直す from a couple levels ago. It means "to fix." So, when you fix the way you see something, what are you doing? You're reevaluating it. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to reevaluate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 見る and 直す. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!

examples.en: I'm in the dentist's waiting room now.
examples.ja: 今、歯医者の待合室にいます。

examples.en: There were many people in the hospital waiting room.
examples.ja: 病院の待合室にはたくさんの人がいました。

examples.en: It was too cold waiting outside for the night bus because there was no waiting room. Please build a waiting room!
examples.ja: 待合室がないので、夜行バスを外で待つのが寒すぎた。待合室作ってくれ！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>join</kanji> other people to <kanji>wait</kanji>. This is a <vocabulary>waiting room</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember how you learned 待合 already? Well throw the on'yomi for 室 on the end of that and you have your reading!

examples.en: I'm wondering if you would allow us to get an interview?
examples.ja: 取材にご協力いただけませんか。

examples.en: I will go to cover the sports event tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は、スポーツイベントの取材に行きます。

examples.en: I'm covering the concert of a famous artist now.
examples.ja: 今は有名アーティストのコンサートの取材をしています。

examples.en: Media coverage started simultaneously.
examples.ja: マスコミの取材が一斉に始まりました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your job is to <kanji>take</kanji> <kanji>material</kanji>s from a bunch of different people because you're <vocabulary>covering an event</vocabulary>. This <vocabulary>data collection</vocabulary> needs to be thorough, so you try to take all the materials you can from as many people as you can find.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi of 取 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're <vocabulary>covering an event</vocabulary> featuring all kinds of <reading>chu</reading>tes (しゅ). They have the whole range, from laundry chutes and garbage chutes, to evacuation chutes and so much more. You'll be doing some <vocabulary>data collection</vocabulary> and interviews about all these chutes, and you can't wait!

examples.en: "Promise?" "Yes. I promise."
examples.ja: 「約束する？」「うん、約束するよ。」

examples.en: Can you promise that you won't tell this to anybody else?
examples.ja: ゼッタイに誰にも言わないって、約束してくれる？

examples.en: I made plans for a date with someone I really like, but I got the flu and now I'm crying because it seems like I won't be able to go.
examples.ja: 大好きな人とデートの約束したんだけど、インフルになって行けそうもなくて泣いてる。

meaning_mnemonic: 約束 is a “promise.” So when you add する to it you’re making it a verb, meaning <vocabulary>to promise</vocabulary>. Now promise you’ll remember!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 約束 with する added. Make sure you know 約束 and you'll know this word as well.

examples.en: Ah, you startled me! Why are you wearing that mask?
examples.ja: わぁ、びっくりした！何で仮面なんてかぶってるの？

examples.en: Behind her smiling mask, she might actually be crying.
examples.ja: 彼女は笑顔の仮面の下で、本当は泣いているのかもしれないよ。

examples.en: On the Halloween night, I saw Viet wearing the Masked Rider costume and eating a whole box of chocolates.
examples.ja: ハロウィンの日の夜、仮面ライダーのコスプレをしながら、チョコレートを一箱平らげたビエトを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> is something you put over your face to cover it. It's a <vocabulary>mask</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The high school I went to was very conservative.
examples.ja: 私の通っていた高校は、とても保守的な学校でした。

examples.en: That artist has many fans with conservative views.
examples.ja: あのアーティストには、保守的な考え方のファンが多い。

examples.en: People tend to become more conservative as they get older, but I don't want to be like that.
examples.ja: 年を重ねるにつれて保守的になる人が多いけど、私はそうはなりたくありません。

meaning_mnemonic: Who are all <kanji>like</kanji> "I want to <kanji>preserve</kanji> and <kanji>protect</kanji> what I have, get out of my business, government!"? <vocabulary>Conservative</vocabulary> people, of course.
reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't match up for this word's 守. The reading is しゅ, but you can remember that because the conservatives want to protect and preserve their <reading>hoe</reading>s (ほ) and their <reading>chute</reading>s (しゅ) from the government. For some reason those get taxed a lot.

Up <vocabulary>conservation</vocabulary> efforts! And, if you want to save data (like on a computer), you can use this word for that kind of <vocabulary>saving</vocabulary>, as well.

Giving <kanji>evidence</kanji> (or a <kanji>guarantee</kanji>) that you will <kanji>preserve</kanji> something, is giving a <vocabulary>guarantee</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>assurance</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>warranty</vocabulary>.

This word is used when the emphasis is on taking responsibility for something, as in a guarantor, a product warranty, or quality assurance.

examples.en: Someone sends a Buddhist statue to our office every month. If you are that person, please come forward and identify yourself.

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>Buddha</kanji> and 像, which you learned mainly as "image" but can also mean <kanji>statue</kanji>. So that makes this a <vocabulary>statue of Buddha</vocabulary>. 仏像 can also just mean an <vocabulary>image of Buddha</vocabulary>, of course.

仏像 refers to statues, paintings, or artistic representations of Buddhist figures used as objects of worship. While it often means Buddha sculptures, it also includes depictions not just of the Buddha himself but other Buddhist deities as well.

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Letter</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji>s can be found in a <vocabulary>character dictionary</vocabulary>. In Japanese, one kanji "letter" or "character" can hold a lot of information, so you have dictionaries dedicated to kanji meanings. That's what this is.

This word is a little old-fashioned these days, so you might also see 漢字辞典 used for a character dictionary. (You'll learn 辞典 soon, if you haven't already!)

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is in danger! It's poor old <reading>abe</reading> (あぶ) Lincoln. You try to save him, yelling out 危ないよ！！！！, but he gets shot in the back of the head anyways.

meaning_mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>below</kanji> normal <kanji>products</kanji> are the cheap knockoffs and bad quality items. These items are incredibly <vocabulary>crude</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vulgar</vocabulary> in their manufacturing and design. So much <vocabulary>vulgarity</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
You haven't seen this reading for 下 yet (sorry there's so many for this kanji!) so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Those items are so <vocabulary>crude</vocabulary> that you can't even tell what they're supposed to be. Honestly they all just look like statues of lumpy <reading>ge</reading>ckos (げ). That says it's a lamp but it looks more like a gecko looking at the sky. That chair? Definitely a bunch of geckos having a pool party. Are you sure you didn't get this stuff from a weird gecko artist?

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>product</kanji>, it's not really a product anymore, but <vocabulary>a work</vocabulary>. It's your <vocabulary>work</vocabulary> of art or literature, or maybe a theater <vocabulary>production</vocabulary>.

This can be any kind of artistic creation: a book, a composition, a painting, a movie, a play... It doesn't mean "product" (you'll learn the word for that later!) but it can be used for a product when you want to highlight the artistic talent behind it.

reading_mnemonic:
When this kanji is used as a single-character vocabulary word, it's usually read as しな. That's the case with this word too! You haven't seen the しな reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Think of the <reading>sheen</reading> (しな) that new <vocabulary>goods</vocabulary> have before you buy them. When you bring them home, that sheen is already gone. But then you go back to the store and, wow! All the goods you don't already own have that sheen! Gotta buy them!

examples.en: I understand that you are very concerned about this.

meaning_mnemonic:
This is like a very formal and humble way of saying <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to believe</vocabulary>. Sure, the kanji means <kanji>suppose</kanji>, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know" or "I believe." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why 存じる means <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to believe</vocabulary>.

Note this word is typically used in the polite ます form. When you’re humble, you may want to be as polite as possible, I suppose!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!
