meaning_mnemonic:
This is the noun version of the kanji 幸. The kanji means <kanji>happiness</kanji> and the vocab word means <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>.

Compared to 幸福, 幸せ is more commonly used in everyday language and refers to a more immediate, personal sense of happiness or contentment.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

On your quest for true <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>, you meet a happiness guru. <reading>She always says</reading> (しあわせ), "just be happy!" She always says that, and you always listen. You can't believe how simple yet profound her approach is!

examples.en: At that moment, I realized that the government wouldn't help the citizens.
examples.ja: その時、政府は市民を助けてくれないんだってことだけ学びました。

examples.en: That journalist always writes articles about the American government.
examples.ja: あのジャーナリストは、いつもアメリカ政府についての記事を書いている。

examples.en: In my country, there's a lot of government support for childcare.
examples.ja: 私の国では、子育てに対する政府からのサポートがたくさんあります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Politics</kanji> and <kanji>government</kanji>. They are needed to keep the <vocabulary>government</vocabulary> rolling.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I was a student, my mother made me homemade bento boxes every day.
examples.ja: 学生の時は、母が毎日手作りのお弁当を作ってくれました。

examples.en: I left some sides in my box lunch and gave them to a kitten.
examples.ja: お弁当のおかずを少し残しておいて、子猫にあげました。

examples.en: I think I’ll make a bento box for you tomorrow. Is there anything you’d prefer not to have?
examples.ja: 明日あなたにお弁当作ってあげようと思うんだけど、何か苦手なものとかあるの？

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 弁 means <kanji>dialect</kanji> and 当 means <kanji>success</kanji>? Well, this isn't going to help you much, because this means <vocabulary>bento</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>box lunch</vocabulary>. Chances are, though, you know the word "bento" from English. So, if you read this word (which you should be able to) you can figure out it's べんとう. If you do that, you can realize this word means <vocabulary>bento</vocabulary> too!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tokyo dialect is almost the same as standard Japanese.
examples.ja: 東京弁は共通語とほとんど同じですよ。

examples.en: I was born and raised in Tokyo, but my parents are from Kyoto, so my Kyoto dialect is stronger than my Tokyo dialect.
examples.ja: 私は東京生まれ東京育ちですが、親が京都出身なので東京弁より京都弁の方が強いです。

examples.en: "I need to get some free Tokyo dialect lessons." "Ask Koichi. He'll do anything."
examples.ja: 「ねえ、タダで東京弁のレッスンを受けたいんだけど。」「コウイチに聞けよ。アイツは何でもするぞ。」

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 東京 is <kanji>Tokyo</kanji>, and you know that 弁 is <kanji>dialect</kanji>, so here you have the <vocabulary>Tokyo dialect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Should be no surprises here, especially if you remember how to read 東京.

examples.en: Which dialect is that?
examples.ja: それって何弁？

examples.en: I like the Kyoto dialect.
examples.ja: 私は京都弁が好きです。

examples.en: I am bilingual because I can speak standard Japanese as well as the Kansai dialect.
examples.ja: 私は日本語の共通語も関西弁も話せるからバイリンガルなんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The 〜 is there to show this attaches onto things, like 東京弁, meaning "Tokyo Dialect."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Because it's normally attached to other words it uses the on'yomi reading like a jukugo word normally would.

examples.en: Sorry, I'm in a bit of a hurry, I'll go first!
examples.ja: ごめん、ちょっと急ぐから先に行くね！

examples.en: Hurry up! If we hurry, we can still make it.
examples.ja: もっと急いでよ！急げばまだ間に合うはずだよ。

examples.en: Koichi rushed to the hospital when he heard that Viet had been brought in.
examples.ja: ビエトが運ばれたと聞いて、コウイチは病院へ急ぎました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hurry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone who is trying <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary> is someone who is not at <reading>ease</reading> (いそ).

examples.en: A matchbox abruptly dropped from the sky.
examples.ja: 急に空からマッチ箱が一箱ふってきたんです。

examples.en: What? Even if you suddenly say such a thing…
examples.ja: えっ、急にそんなことを言われても...。

examples.en: Family Guy is famous for its random and stupid flashbacks.
examples.ja: ファミリー・ガイは、急にバカげた回想シーンを使うことで良く知られている。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that happens in a <kanji>sudden</kanji> way happens <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>immediately</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>abruptly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. <vocabulary>Suddenly</vocabulary> you can read a new word!

examples.en: I was a high school student when my dad suddenly passed away.
examples.ja: 父が急死した時、私は高校生でした。

examples.en: Apparently, the old man at Maru-chan's place died suddenly when a sticky rice cake got stuck in his throat.
examples.ja: マルちゃんのところのおじいさん、モチがノドにつまって急死だったんだって。

examples.en: I often argued with my boyfriend and I hated it, but I even miss the arguments now. I never expected that he would drop dead.
examples.ja: 彼とはよくケンカになっちゃって、それが本当にイヤだったんだけど、今ではケンカもできなくなっちゃってすっごく悲しいよ。まさか急死しちゃうなんて思ってもみなかったからさ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> makes for just that, a <vocabulary>sudden death</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It seems like the express train bound for Kyoto departs from platform three.
examples.ja: 京都行き急行は三番乗り場から出るみたいだよ。

examples.en: I saw a patrol car rushing somewhere around that corner.
examples.ja: あそこの角で、どこかに急行するパトカーを見ました。

examples.en: The voice of the person making announcements on the express train I rode today had an amazing, captivating voice!
examples.ja: 今日乗った急行列車の車内放送の人の声、めっちゃイケボだった！

meaning_mnemonic: Things that <kanji>hurry</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> faster than the other things are <vocabulary>express</vocabulary>. This is often used with trains or subways, so look out for it if you're looking to get somewhere in a hurry. Also be careful in case it doesn't stop at your stop, because 急行 trains don't stop at every station (which is what makes them express!).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are too many people in Japan who are not interested in politics.
examples.ja: 日本は政治に関心がない人が多すぎます。

examples.en: Salmon's attitude toward the government is very conservative.
examples.ja: サーモンの政治に対する考えはとても保守的です。

examples.en: Do you know what politics is for? It's to protect the lives of the citizens and to absolutely prevent war.
examples.ja: 政治って何のためのものか分かりますか？国民の生活を守るためと、ゼッタイに戦争をしないためですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>cure</kanji> the <kanji>government</kanji>, you have to get into <vocabulary>politics</vocabulary>. Gotta join 'em to fix them... but can you survive that long without being corrupted yourself?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I need to think of what to blog about!
examples.ja: ブログに書くこと考えなきゃ！

examples.en: The notes I had written down went somewhere.
examples.ja: せっかく書いたメモがどこかに行ってしまった。

examples.en: Koichi's handwriting is far from being good.
examples.ja: コウイチは、お世辞にも字を書くのが上手だとは言えません。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>write</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to write</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the on'yomi one, but this word is read with the kun'yomi, か. So just be sure to remember the kun'yomi reading to read this word in the <reading>ca</reading>r (か) ... or <vocabulary>to write</vocabulary> it, or whatever.

examples.en: It seems like it will take about six months to fully recover.
examples.ja: 全治六ヶ月みたい。

examples.en: I was hit by a truck and got a bad injury that will take a year to heal completely.
examples.ja: トラックにはねられて全治一年の大ケガをしました。

examples.en: My child got a stress fracture during gym class, and the doctor said it would take two months to heal. But at first, the principal said something like, "Crying over something like this..." Isn't that awful?
examples.ja: うちの子、体育で骨にヒビが入って全治二ヶ月だったんですが、最初は校長先生から「これぐらいでこんなに泣くなんて…」みたいに言われてたんですよ。ありえなくないですか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>cure</kanji>d! That means you've made a <vocabulary>complete recovery</vocabulary>! You're <vocabulary>completely healed</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That disease is currently still considered incurable.
examples.ja: その病気は今はまだ不治の病とされています。

examples.en: He's incurably addicted to social media, so there's no hope for him anymore.
examples.ja: アイツは不治のSNS中毒だから、もうダメだよ。

examples.en: Rather than battling an incurable suffering, I might choose euthanasia.
examples.ja: 私は不治の苦しみと戦うよりも、安楽死する方を選ぶかもしれません。

meaning_mnemonic: When you can <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>cure</kanji> something, this is a problem of <vocabulary>incurability</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My grandmother was born in the Meiji era.
examples.ja: 私のおばあちゃんは明治生まれです。

examples.en: I'm writing an essay about Meiji literature.
examples.ja: 明治文学についての作文を書いています。

examples.en: During the Meiji era, ten thousand yen was a large sum of money.
examples.ja: 明治時代は一万円が大金だったんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: It’s the era of <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji>! If this doesn't make sense, don't worry about it. Focus more on the reading, which is めいじ. Sound familiar? This is the famous <vocabulary>Meiji era</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Meiji Emperor</vocabulary>. If you don't know about it consider reading up, it's interesting history!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 明 (めい) with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The <vocabulary>Meiji era began</vocabulary> with a lot of changes — and by <reading>May</reading> (めい), the new Japan was already shaped.

examples.en: My dog likes to take showers.
examples.ja: ウチの犬はシャワーを浴びるのが好きです。

examples.en: This is a picture of a morning glory in the morning sun.
examples.ja: これは朝日を浴びるアサガオの写真です。

examples.en: For Christmas, I plan to stay home and watch as much Japanese anime as I can.
examples.ja: クリスマスは家にこもって日本のアニメを浴びるほど見るつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bathe</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bathe in</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive, and the object is whatever you're "bathing in". It could be a bath or a shower, but it could also be the sun. So you can both シャワーを浴びる and 日の光を浴びる. More negatively, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be exposed to</vocabulary> something, such as criticism or radioactivity.
reading_mnemonic: You want to know the best way <vocabulary>to bathe in</vocabulary> something? With a bunch of <reading>a</reading>ardvarks (あ) in the water. They use their sticky little tongues to clean all your cracks and crannies.

examples.en: I want to sunbathe on Totoro's big belly.
examples.ja: トトロの大きなおなかの上に乗って日光浴がしたいです。

examples.en: My policy is not to bathe, but to sunbathe on weekdays.
examples.ja: 私は平日は日光浴だけで入浴はしないポリシーなんです。

examples.en: The Tofugu dog loves to sunbathe on the balcony.
examples.ja: トーフグのワンコは、ベランダで日光浴をするのが大好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 日光 is "sunlight" so when you add <kanji>bathe</kanji> you get "sunlight bathe" ... but that sounds dumb, so let's call this word <vocabulary>sunbathe</vocabulary> instead!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We decided, spur of the moment, to take the limited express.
examples.ja: ノリで特急に乗ることに決めました。

examples.en: How much is the limited express fare?
examples.ja: 特急料金はいくらですか？

examples.en: I already got a ticket for you, so if you leave now you can still catch the 3:50 express train.
examples.ja: チケットを先に買っておいたので、今出れば三時五十分の特急に間に合うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>special</kanji> and in a <kanji>hurry</kanji> must be special indeed. This refers to <vocabulary>limited express train</vocabulary>s in Japan. They go fast, they stop at fewer stops (because they're special!) and they hurry. Look out for these if you want to get somewhere in a jiffy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the とく goes to とっ.

examples.en: I studied at Beijing University in 2013.
examples.ja: 私は2013年に北京大学に留学しました。

examples.en: When I studied abroad, I practiced speaking Japanese naturally a lot.
examples.ja: 留学先で、日本語を自然にしゃべる練習をたくさんしました。

examples.en: "My older brother didn't obey the orders of our parents and left to study abroad." "Where is he studying abroad?" "It's in the U.S."
examples.ja: 「兄は親の言いつけを守らず、留学してしまいました。」「留学先はどこなんですか？」「アメリカです。」

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>detain</kanji> your <kanji>study</kanji> and take it away to a foreign place. That foreign place is having you <vocabulary>study abroad</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 留 is the りゅう version. You can remember this because <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from street fighter is doing a study abroad program to learn more karate.

examples.en: Can I post photos of this place on social media?
examples.ja: ここの写真をSNSに上げてもいいですか？

examples.en: Look at this photo. Dad hasn't changed at all since then. Well, he's gained some weight, but nothing else has changed, right?
examples.ja: この写真、見て！お父さん、昔のまんま。変わったことと言えば、ちょっと太ったことくらいじゃない？

examples.en: Koichi's picture from high school was leaked.
examples.ja: コウイチの高校時代の写真が流出してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>copy</kanji> of <kanji>reality</kanji> is a lot like magic. How do you make a copy of reality, though? You take a <vocabulary>photo</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Koichi loves pure black garlic.
examples.ja: コウイチは真っ黒なニンニクが好きなんです。

examples.en: Viet came back from the beach in Hawaii with a dark tan.
examples.ja: ビエトはハワイのビーチで真っ黒に日やけして帰ってきました。

examples.en: These colored contacts show up super well, even on pitch-black pupils!
examples.ja: このカラコン、黒目が真っ黒でもめっちゃ発色するよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>reality</kanji> is that it's <kanji>black</kanji>. Like, so black that it's beyond fake black, it's reality black. This is so black it's <vocabulary>pitch black</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 真 is the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet. Think of what is pitch black. It's your poor <reading>Ma</reading> (ま). She is so dark that she sucks in light, like a black hole... wait, she is a black hole, it explains why your Ma is pitch black.

examples.en: The cornflower's (yagurumagiku) flower meaning is 'happiness'.
examples.ja: ヤグルマギクの花言葉は「幸福」です。

examples.en: In my case, I feel like I'd be happier with a job where I don't have to do things I don't want to do, rather than being able to do what I want.
examples.ja: 私の場合は、「やりたいことができる」より「やりたくないことをやらなくていい」仕事の方が幸福度が高い気がします。

examples.en: Even if people walk the same path in life, some may feel happiness while others may feel unhappiness. Whether it's happiness or unhappiness depends solely on "how you perceive that life," that's all there is to it.
examples.ja: 同じ人生を歩んでいても、幸福と感じる人もいれば、不幸と感じる人もいる。幸福か不幸かは、「あなたがその人生をどう切り取って見るか」、それだけなんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
With a little <kanji>happiness</kanji> and <kanji>luck</kanji> you can achieve <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>, though that goes without saying.

幸福 is often used to discuss happiness in a broader, more abstract sense, like the happiness of a population or the concept of happiness in philosophical contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My grandma said, 'If you laugh at others, it will come back to you.'
examples.ja: 人のことを笑うと自分にも返ってくる、おばあちゃんが言ってたよ。

examples.en: This is funny. I laughed out loud.
examples.ja: これは面白い。大声で笑いました。

examples.en: "I had a date with Fugu last night." "How did it go?" "It was fun. I laughed a lot."
examples.ja: 「昨夜、フグとデートをしたの。」「どうだった？」「楽しかった。めちゃくちゃ笑ったわ。」

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>laugh</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to laugh</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can laugh freely, now!

examples.en: I seriously love your smile!
examples.ja: 君の笑顔がマジで大好きなんだよ！

examples.en: The prince's smile made both the king and queen melt.
examples.ja: 王子の笑顔に、王様も女王様もメロメロでした。

examples.en: I wish you all a wonderful day with a smile on your face...
examples.ja: 皆様が、今日も笑顔でステキな一日になりますように…

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>laugh</kanji>ing <kanji>face</kanji> is a <vocabulary> smiling face</vocabulary> (or just a <vocabulary>smile</vocabulary>!). 笑顔s all around!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word won't make you <vocabulary>smile</vocabulary>, though. You were smiling, but then you heard about the reading of this kanji. It made you yell out "<reading>EH</reading>??" (え). Just watch out for the rendaku of かお to がお.

examples.en: Where is the trash can?
examples.ja: ゴミ箱はどこですか？

examples.en: We need a trash can in this room.
examples.ja: この部屋にはゴミ箱が必要です。

examples.en: The recycling bin for plastic bottles is next to the trash can.
examples.ja: ペットボトルのリサイクルボックスはゴミ箱の横にあります。

meaning_mnemonic: ゴミ means "garbage." Add a <kanji>box</kanji> to it and you have a garbage box aka a <vocabulary>garbage can</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>garbage bin</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading, the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku though. はこ changes to ばこ.

examples.en: Be careful with this box; it's heavy.
examples.ja: この箱、重いから気をつけてね。

examples.en: This cardboard box contains unwanted clothes.
examples.ja: このダンボール箱には、いらなくなった服が入っています。

examples.en: My husband bought a box of tomatoes, and we are struggling to finish them.
examples.ja: 夫がトマトを箱で買ってきて、食べきれなくてこまっています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Backpacks are convenient for carrying luggage.
examples.ja: 荷物を持ち運ぶには、バックパックが便利です。

examples.en: She hurriedly packed her belongings into a large suitcase.
examples.ja: 彼女は急いで大きなスーツケースに荷物を入れました。

examples.en: I've sent the package over there! It should arrive in about three days.
examples.ja: 荷物、そっちに送ったよ！三日ぐらいで着くみたい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>luggage</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is your <vocabulary>luggage</vocabulary>. It's also your <vocabulary>baggage</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>load</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the 物 reading as もつ, though. Why? Because all your luggage just got thrown into various <reading>moats</reading> along the countryside. It's going to take you forever to collect your luggage from these moats and by then it'll be all soggy. Dangit...

examples.en: As proof of our friendship, I'll give you this Mt. Fuji keychain.
examples.ja: 友情の証として、このふじ山のキーホルダーをあげます。

examples.en: That's evidence that he cares about you, isn't it?
examples.ja: それって、彼が君のことを大切にしている証なんじゃないかな。

examples.en: Behold! This crystal is the proof of the king's authority!
examples.ja: 見よ。このクリスタルこそが、王の証なのだ！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 
Your relentless search for <vocabulary>evidence</vocabulary> has finally uncovered the existence of <reading>a</reading> <reading>car</reading> <reading>shee</reading>p (あかし)! It's a bizarre hybrid, having a car's body but a sheep's head and legs. "Ah, car sheep! I've finally found the evidence proving you're real!"

examples.en: There are no witnesses.
examples.ja: 証人はいません。

examples.en: I am also one of the witnesses.
examples.ja: 私も証人の一人です。

examples.en: He is a Jehovah's Witness.
examples.ja: 彼はエホバの証人です。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>evidence</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>witness</vocabulary>, because witnesses are people who provide evidence (you know, with their mouths or something).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: All of the Tofugu workers testified that they had seen Koichi eat Viet's meatball.
examples.ja: 全トーフグ社員が、コウイチがビエトのミートボールを食べるのを見たと証言しました。

examples.en: Only Michael refused because he didn't want to testify against Koichi.
examples.ja: マイケルだけは、コウイチに不利な証言はしたくないと言って、証言しませんでした。

examples.en: When Fugu allegedly put blowfish poison in the teacher's apple, all of his classmates testified that he did not do it.
examples.ja: フグが先生のリンゴにフグ毒を付けたと疑われた時、クラスメート全員が彼はやってないと証言しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Evidence</kanji> that you <kanji>say</kanji> is <vocabulary>testimony</vocabulary>. You could also say you're providing <vocabulary>verbal evidence</vocabulary>. Hopefully you won't have to give too much of this in your lifetime.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This dictionary app is recommended.
examples.ja: この辞書アプリ、おすすめだよ。

examples.en: This is the best selling dictionary in the world.
examples.ja: これは、世界で一番売れている辞書です。

examples.en: Since I like using paper dictionaries, they tend to get worn out quickly.
examples.ja: 私は紙の辞書を引くのが好きなので、すぐにボロボロになります。

meaning_mnemonic: Take all the <kanji>word</kanji>s you use in <kanji>writing</kanji>, put them together and you have a <vocabulary>dictionary</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, you're leaving the company?
examples.ja: え、会社辞めるの？

examples.en: I actually quit my part-time job yesterday.
examples.ja: 実は昨日、バイト辞めたんだ。

examples.en: On Sunday nights, all I can think about is "I want to quit my job."
examples.ja: 日曜の夜は「仕事辞めたい」しか考えられない。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>quit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to quit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going <vocabulary>to quit</vocabulary>?" "<reading>Yah</reading> (や) man, I'm going to quit."

examples.en: Koichi is not good at giving insincere compliments.
examples.ja: コウイチは心にもないお世辞を言うのが下手です。

examples.en: I don't like being told that my Japanese is good just to flatter me.
examples.ja: お世辞で日本語が上手だと言われるのは好きではありません。

examples.en: Hmm, there's no way to sugarcoat it: this just isn't well done.
examples.ja: うーん、これはお世辞にも上手とは言えないね。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>quit</kanji> your current <kanji>generation</kanji> to join an older one, you'll need to use all kinds of <vocabulary>flattery</vocabulary>. Older people love being flattered; so be nice and give them some <vocabulary>compliment</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Just watch out, as the 世 gets shortened from せい to せ! You can memorize this by remembering to be short and sweet with your flattery, don't make it too long and overcomplicated!

examples.en: Koichi's apartment is located about three hours from the Tofugu office, in some faraway woods.
examples.ja: コウイチのアパートはトーフグオフィスから三時間ほど行った、遠い林の中にあります。

examples.en: That condo was really nice but we gave up on buying it, because it was too far from the station.
examples.ja: あのマンション、とてもよかったんですけど、駅から遠すぎて買うのをあきらめました。

examples.en: How far is Tokyo from Portland? Is it too far for me to walk?
examples.ja: 東京は、ポートランドからどれくらい遠いんですか？歩くにはちょっと遠すぎますか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>far</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>far</vocabulary> (or it's <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: You want to go <vocabulary>far</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary> when you see a <reading>toe... oh</reading> (とお)! You realize there is a zombie toe on the ground and it reminds you of where you can go that's far from here—where the zombie that once had this toe went! (Remember the kanji mnemonic? It's that scooter zombie's toe that makes you say oh and want to go.)

examples.en: Let's start with the introductory course first.
examples.ja: まずは入門コースから始めましょう。

examples.en: I heard he started his training under a famous yoga instructor.
examples.ja: 彼は有名なヨガの先生のところに入門したそうですよ。

examples.en: This book is an introductory text on programming.
examples.ja: この本はプログラミングの入門書です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you are able to <kanji>enter</kanji> the <kanji>gate</kanji> then you have gained <vocabulary>admission</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>entrance</vocabulary> to the facility.  Sometimes you do this to start an <vocabulary>apprenticeship</vocabulary>, where you get an <vocabulary>introduction</vocabulary> to some sweet new skills, like how to make an entrance.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is your opinion on this issue?
examples.ja: この問題に関するあなたの意見を教えてください。

examples.en: Sayaka is conducting research on Japanese literature.
examples.ja: サヤカは、日本文学に関する研究を行っています。

examples.en: I have a question regarding Japanese grammar.
examples.ja: 日本語の文法に関して、聞きたいことがあるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 関 means <kanji>related</kanji>. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to be related to</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: What kind of relationship do you two have?
examples.ja: 二人はどういう関係なの？

examples.en: That's irrelevant now, right?
examples.ja: それは今は関係ないでしょ？

examples.en: It seems like Viet has a deep connection with the yakuza.
examples.ja: ビエトはヤクザとズブズブの関係らしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>connection</kanji> <kanji>related</kanji> to another <kanji>connection</kanji> obviously has some kind of <vocabulary>connection</vocabulary>, at least between all those meanings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We're planning to go via the Hanshin train.
examples.ja: 阪神電車で行く予定です。

examples.en: I'm a fan of the Hanshin Tigers.
examples.ja: 私は阪神タイガースのファンです。

examples.en: I am thinking about buying a house in the Hanshin district. About how much is the market price?
examples.ja: 今度、阪神地区に家を買おうと思ってるんですが、相場はいくらぐらいなんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>slope</kanji>s of the <kanji>god</kanji>s! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as <vocabulary>Hanshin</vocabulary>. They're based in the area between Osaka and Kobe. Think of it this way: 大阪 + 神戸 = 阪神! They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The design on the front of this T-shirt is really great.
examples.ja: このTシャツは前面のデザインがすごく良い。

examples.en: The udon soup I had at a restaurant in Canada surprisingly had a strong taste of onions upfront.
examples.ja: カナダのレストランで食べたウドンのスープは、玉ねぎの味が前面に出ている感じで少しびっくりした。

examples.en: At this time, Viet came to stand at the forefront of the movement to make Taco Day a national holiday.
examples.ja: この時、ビエトは「タコスの日」を祭日にしようという運動の前面に立つようになった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>front</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>front side</vocabulary> of it (kind of like how 外面 is the exterior because it's the outside face). This also means <vocabulary>fore</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>forefront</vocabulary>, especially when used metaphorically.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many leaves on the ground.
examples.ja: 地面にはたくさんの葉っぱが落ちていました。

examples.en: I'll take the dog for a short walk before the ground gets soaked from the rain.
examples.ja: 雨で地面がビシャビシャになる前にワンコをちょっと歩かせてくるよ。

examples.en: Fugu said that he'd rather live underground than underwater.
examples.ja: 海の中じゃなくて地面の中に住めたらいいのに、とフグは言いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji>/<kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> is the surface that makes up the <vocabulary>ground</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>Earth's surface</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 面 is what you'd expect. 地 on the other hand is じ, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.

examples.en: You shouldn’t be fooled by her outward appearance.
examples.ja: 彼女の外面にだまされない方がいいですよ。

examples.en: He has a good outward appearance and always smiles in public.
examples.ja: 彼は外面が良く、人前ではいつも笑顔を見せています。

examples.en: These glasses have a flat curvature on the outer surface of the lens, so there's less distortion and glare in the peripheral areas.
examples.ja: このメガネは、レンズの外面のカーブをフラットにしているので、周辺部のボヤケやユガミが少ないんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> to something is the <vocabulary>external appearance</vocabulary> of that thing.

While 外面 can refer to the outer surface of an object, it’s more commonly used to describe someone's <vocabulary>outward appearance</vocabulary>, behavior, or demeanor on the <vocabulary>surface</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, so this is がいめん. But note that this can also use the kun’yomi readings, which makes it そとづら.

While がいめん is neutral, そとづら is a bit negative, often implying that the person's outward appearance might be deceptive, hiding their true nature.

examples.en: If you stare at computer screens for a long time, your eyesight will get worse.
examples.ja: ずっとコンピューターの画面ばかり見ていると目が悪くなるよ。

examples.en: Can I ask you to turn down the screen brightness a bit?
examples.ja: 画面の明るさをもう少し下げてもらってもいいですか？

examples.en: Lately, images of dogs often pop up on my screen automatically.
examples.ja: 最近、よく犬の画像が自動で画面に出てくるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>image</kanji> <kanji>surface</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen</vocabulary>. Just imagine your computer screen. There's an image on the surface, right? It just happens to move around all the time, like most images on screens these days.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have something to talk to you about face-to-face. When are you available?
examples.ja: あなたに、面と向かってお話したいことがあります。ご予定は、いつが空いていますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: That was the funniest thing I’ve ever heard.
examples.ja: それは今まで聞いた中で、一番面白い話でした。

examples.en: This manga is a bit crude but it's very interesting.
examples.ja: このマンガは、ちょっと下品だけどとても面白いんです。

examples.en: He is an amusing guy, his only downside is that he gets angry over the smallest things.
examples.ja: あいつは面白いやつだけど、ちょっとしたことですぐ切れるのがネックだよな。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>face</kanji> of this object is so <kanji>white</kanji>! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so <vocabulary>interesting</vocabulary>...
reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the 面 part (白い is just like the vocab word 白い). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "<reading>Oh mo</reading>!" (おも) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.

examples.en: I found a new book at the library.
examples.ja: 図書館で新しい本を見つけました。

examples.en: Library use is free of charge.
examples.ja: 図書館の利用にお金はかかりませんよ。

examples.en: I like studying at the library.
examples.ja: 私は図書館で勉強するのが好きなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>public building</kanji> where <kanji>writte</kanji>n things are all <kanji>diagram</kanji>ed out in a way that lets you find said written things? That sounds like a <vocabulary>library</vocabulary> to me!
reading_mnemonic: The 書館 part should be readable by you, but it's the 図 that's troublesome with an alternate reading from the one you learned. Imagine yourself at the library. You check out every single book you can about the human <reading>toe</reading> (と). You have a giant stack of books on it, then you drop it... ironically on your toe. You decide to <reading>show Khan</reading> (your buddy) your smashed toe.

examples.en: He is a world-renowned chef.
examples.ja: 彼は世界的に有名な料理人です。

examples.en: My girlfriend works as a cook in a restaurant.
examples.ja: 僕の彼女は料理人としてレストランで働いています。

examples.en: Chefs also need to pay attention to the presentation of their dishes.
examples.ja: 料理人は料理のプレゼンテーションにも気を配らなくてはなりません。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 料理 and probably know it means "cooking." So, what is a <kanji>person</kanji> who does cooking? That is <vocabulary>a cook</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>chef</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He isn't a famous artist.
examples.ja: 彼は有名な芸術家ではありません。

examples.en: She is a globally renowned artist who has received numerous awards.
examples.ja: 彼女は、多くの賞を受賞している、世界的に名の知れた芸術家です。

examples.en: The artist asked his disciple to look after his house while he was away and left for Europe to study.
examples.ja: その芸術家は、弟子に留守番をたのんで、ヨーロッパに留学しました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 芸術 is <kanji>art</kanji> so you'd think that 芸術家 would be something like "art house." Well, it's not. Think of it this way: Who is the person who works for "House Art"? It's the <vocabulary>artist</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This train's doors don't open automatically.
examples.ja: この電車のドアは、自動的には開きません。

examples.en: If that country starts a war, our country will automatically be drawn into the conflict as well.
examples.ja: あの国が戦争を始めると、俺たちの国も自動的に戦うことになるんだよ。

examples.en: The data automatically backed up here is managed by a system that will also automatically delete it after a certain period of time.
examples.ja: こちらに自動的にバックアップされたデータは、今度は一定期間後に自動的に消去されるシステムになっています。

examples.en: This is due to an automatic logout after more than 30 minutes of inactivity.
examples.ja: これは、30分以上何もしなかった場合の自動的なログアウトによるものですね。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>automatic</kanji><kanji>al</kanji> (自動 + 的) thing of course isn't "automatical." A better way to say it is to cut off the -al and call it <vocabulary>automatic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the reading of 自動 as well.

examples.en: I generally don't believe in spiritual matters.
examples.ja: 私は基本的にはスピリチュアルな事は信じません。

examples.en: I was told by my boss that I don't even know the fundamentals and that I'm useless.
examples.ja: 上司に、基本的な事も知らない役立たずだと言われました。

examples.en: Basically, I have no interest in politics.
examples.ja: 基本的に政治に関心がないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The things that are <kanji>basics</kanji> (基本) <kanji>like</kanji> (的) are <vocabulary>basic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fundamental</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing how to read the word 基本 will be helpful too.

examples.en: He reads books without ever creasing the pages.
examples.ja: 彼はゼッタイに折り目をつけずに本を読みます。

examples.en: Please open the origami again after you fold it in half to add the crease.
examples.ja: 折り紙を半分に折って、折り目をつけてからまた開いてください。

examples.en: Could you put a crease in my trousers?
examples.ja: ズボンには折り目を付けてもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fold</kanji> you can see with your <kanji>eye</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fold</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crease</vocabulary> in something.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings. You should have seen 折る by now which should help you to read 折り. Then there's 目, which I'm guessing you won't have a problem with.

examples.en: Tomorrow is my graduation ceremony.
examples.ja: 明日は私の卒業式です。

examples.en: Ah, this is a photo from after the graduation ceremony, right? How nostalgic!
examples.ja: あ、これ、卒業式の後の写真だね。なつかしい！

examples.en: Huh? Did you say that Beyoncé came to the graduation and sang for you guys? No way! You must be joking!
examples.ja: はあ？卒業式にビヨンセが来て歌を歌ってくれた？まさか！冗談でしょう？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 卒業 is <kanji>graduation</kanji> so what about when you add <kanji>ceremony</kanji> to it? That makes it a <vocabulary>graduation ceremony</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 卒業 already as a word, too.

examples.en: Everyone is imperfect.
examples.ja: 人間はみんな不完全です。

examples.en: Aren't incomplete things better than complete things, since they have a humanness about them?
examples.ja: 完全なものよりも不完全なものの方が人情味があってよくない？

examples.en: The Tofugu softball team had an incomplete end to their season when the game they were winning was suspended due to rain.
examples.ja: 勝ち試合が雨で中止になり、トーフグソフトボールチームのシーズンが不完全に終わった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 完全 means "complete" or "perfect." So, a <kanji>not</kanji> "complete" or "perfect" is something that is <vocabulary>incomplete</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>imperfect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read 完全.

examples.en: I went to an art museum workshop.
examples.ja: 美術館のワークショップに行ってきました。

examples.en: We had an art museum date over the weekend.
examples.ja: 週末は美術館デートでした。

examples.en: When I went to the Louvre Museum in Paris, I saw famous artworks like the "Mona Lisa."
examples.ja: パリのルーヴル美術館に行った時に「モナリザ」などの有名なアート作品を見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know 美術 is <kanji>fine art</kanji>. So what is a <kanji>public building</kanji> that contains said fine art? It's a <vocabulary>museum</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm a professional origami artist.
examples.ja: 私はプロの折り紙アーティストです。

examples.en: I stockpiled everyday items, cosmetics, groceries, and origami paper during the Amazon sale.
examples.ja: Amazonのセールで、日用品、コスメ、食料品、折り紙を買いだめしました。

examples.en: Today, Koichi found origami instead of food in his bento box.
examples.ja: 今日のコウイチの弁当箱の中には、なぜか食べ物の代わりに折り紙が入っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 折る is "to fold," so what about "to fold <kanji>paper</kanji>"? Ever heard of something that involves lots of folding of paper that is Japanese? Most likely you have. This is <vocabulary>origami</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>art of paper folding</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 折る and the vocab word 紙. As long as you know those you should be able to read this. Also, you probably already know this reading because it's an English word, too.

examples.en: I hope you can get into the university of your choice!
examples.ja: 希望する大学に入学できるといいですね！

examples.en: I'm hoping to study abroad in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本への留学を希望しています。

examples.en: I'll do my best to schedule shifts for you according to your preferences, but sometimes adjustments may be necessary if everyone's preferences don't align. Thank you for your understanding in this matter.
examples.ja: できるだけ希望するシフトでバイトに入ってもらえるようにしますが、みんなの希望が合わない時は調整が必要なこともあるので、そこはよろしくお願いします。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 希望 is a "wish." When you "do a wish," that means <vocabulary>to wish</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hope</vocabulary>.

This is a formal way to say that you wish for something, so you might use it at work to request an opportunity to work abroad, or let them know politely that you're resigning.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 希望. It's also the on'yomi jukugo reading as well, if that helps any.

examples.en: I'm not a doctor, but I learned surgical techniques from a doctor.
examples.ja: 私は医者ではありませんが、ある医者から、手術の技術を学びました。

examples.en: I learned the latest web development skills from the company I used to work for.
examples.ja: 以前に働いていた会社で、ウエブ開発の最新技術を身につけました。

examples.en: During the presentation, a Google engineer suddenly stood up and started singing karaoke.
examples.ja: プレゼン中、グーグルの技術者が急に立ち上がり、カラオケを始めたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 技 as a vocab word meaning "technique," and the kanji 術 means <kanji>technique</kanji>. So this means <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary>! Your technique is also your <vocabulary>craft</vocabulary>, and what’s needed for <vocabulary>technology</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'll compromise on 100,000 yen.
examples.ja: 十万円で妥協するよ。

examples.en: Koichi and Viet compromised by going to McDonald's.
examples.ja: コウイチとビエトは、マクドナルドに行くことで妥協しました。

examples.en: After all, you don't want to compromise on the design and interior of your own home, right?
examples.ja: やっぱり、自分の家のデザインやインテリアは妥協したくないじゃん。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 妥協 means <kanji>compromise</kanji>. So, what happens when you make it a verb? It becomes <vocabulary>to compromise</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the vocab word 妥協, so if you know that you should be good (also, just the reading of the kanji works too).

examples.en: They found out that I'd cheated and I was rejected.
examples.ja: カンニングしたのがバレて不合格になってしまった。

examples.en: If you don't mind, could you tell me the reason I wasn't accepted?
examples.ja: もしよければ、不合格になった理由を教えてもらえませんか？

examples.en: I didn't get accepted into my first-choice public university, but I got into a private university that I applied to as a safety.
examples.ja: 本命の公立大学は不合格だったが、すべり止めで受けた私立大学に合格しました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 合格する is "to pass a test," so what's the opposite of that? <vocabulary>Fail a test</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>failure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the reading for 合格, all you have to do is add 不 to it! You've learned all these readings, yay!

examples.en: What if I told you that I was planning to graduate from this industry soon?
examples.ja: この業界、そろそろ卒業するつもりなんだって言ったらどうする？

examples.en: I can't wait to finish school, but I don't want to grow up.
examples.ja: 学校は早く卒業したいけど、大人にはなりたくないな。

examples.en: Is it possible to graduate from art school or an art college and still not find a job in art?
examples.ja: 美大や芸大を卒業しても、アートの仕事が見つからないこともあるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 卒業 is "graduation." Make it a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to graduate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the same as the vocab word 卒業.

examples.en: It is not good to leave behind food.
examples.ja: 食べ物を残すのは良くないですよ。

examples.en: I left a comment on your blog.
examples.ja: ブログにコメントを残しました。

examples.en: I intend to be a big name in the world someday.
examples.ja: いつか世に名を残せるような大物になるつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>remainder</kanji>, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about <vocabulary>to leave behind</vocabulary>. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of す. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would <reading>sue</reading> you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word can come from level 14 item 残る. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.

examples.en: This is a recipe for a rare cheese cake that hardens in the microwave without gelatin or flame.
examples.ja: これはゼラチンも火も使わずにレンジでチンして固めるレアチーズケーキのレシピです。

examples.en: Viet takes an hour to make his pompadour hard every morning.
examples.ja: ビエトは毎朝一時間かけてリーゼントをワックスで固めます。

examples.en: Koichi was determined to make WaniKani the best Japanese language learning site in the world.
examples.ja: コウイチは、ワニカニを世界一の日本語学習サイトにする決意を固めた。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hard</kanji> so the verb vocab version? <vocabulary>To make something hard</vocabulary>. You need to differentiate this from 固まる, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make something hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "<reading>mail</reading>" (める) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you.
reading_mnemonic:
Since the reading for 固 (かた) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Why would you want <vocabulary>to make something hard</vocabulary>? Obviously because you want to put it in a <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた). There's no point putting soft things in catapults, after all.

examples.en: Do you have something to verify your identity?
examples.ja: 何か身分を証明できる物は持っていますか？

examples.en: I need a certified photo with date stamp.
examples.ja: 日付スタンプのある証明写真が必要なんです。

examples.en: Please show me proof that you have finished up to level sixty of WaniKani. If you don't prove it, I won't believe you.
examples.ja: ワニカニのレベル60まで終わったっていう証明を見せてください。証明がないなら信じませんよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Is the <kanji>evidence</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> enough to convince me? Is this really <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary> enough to <vocabulary>prove</vocabulary> it?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 明 (めい) with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

You need to show me <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary> to make me believe in the month of <reading>May</reading> (めい). Does it even exist? It may or may not be real (that's why it's called May), so you have to <vocabulary>prove</vocabulary> it to me somehow.

examples.en: What day of the week is today?
examples.ja: 今日って何曜日だっけ？

examples.en: I have Japanese lessons on Wednesdays.
examples.ja: 水曜日は、日本語のレッスンがあります。

examples.en: At our place, we have decided on dinner menus for each day of the week.
examples.ja: うちの家では、曜日ごとに夕飯のメニューを決めてるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>weekday</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is the <vocabulary>day of the week</vocabulary>, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn 曜日 to get you prepared.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 曜 and the kun'yomi reading for 日. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because ひ of 日 changes to び here.

examples.en: I was born in Osaka.
examples.ja: 私は生まれは大阪です。

examples.en: Osaka has a lot of delicious food.
examples.ja: 大阪には美味しい食べ物がたくさんあります。

examples.en: I was so excited about the Osaka trip that I totally neglected my studies.
examples.ja: 大阪旅行が楽しみすぎて、勉強がすっかりお留守になってしまっていました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>heights</kanji>. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is <vocabulary>Osaka</vocabulary>. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The 大 reads like おお from おおきい. Then, 阪 uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like 坂, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen 坂 you can apply that reading over to here, making おおさか. Then again, if you know this word means <vocabulary>Osaka</vocabulary> you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double おお though!

examples.en: He's not interested in others, you know.
examples.ja: アイツは他人に関心がないんだよ。

examples.en: In our case, my father had absolutely zero concern in parenting.
examples.ja: うちの場合は、父親の子育てへの関心がゼロだったんですよね。

examples.en: Everyone, please take more interest in politics.
examples.ja: 皆さん、もっと政治に関心を持ってください。

meaning_mnemonic: The things <kanji>related</kanji> to your <kanji>heart</kanji> are the things that <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>interest</vocabulary> you the most.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's a really great plan!
examples.ja: すごくいい企画ですね！

examples.en: I'm currently working on planning the Christmas event.
examples.ja: 今、クリスマスイベントの企画を進めてるんだ。

examples.en: It was a plan I worked hard on, but it got scrapped.
examples.ja: がんばって考えた企画だったけど、ボツになったよ。

examples.en: We're planning a company retreat at the beginning of next year.
examples.ja: 来年の頭に、社員旅行を企画しています。

examples.en: Nice to meet you. I am Koichi, the head of project management.
examples.ja: 初めまして。私は事業企画部部長のコウイチと申します。

meaning_mnemonic:
Take your <kanji>plan</kanji> and add some <kanji>image</kanji>s to it. This is your <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary>.

While 計画 refers to plans in general, 企画 specifically refers to the planning of events, projects, or initiatives, as well as the actual projects being planned.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

examples.en: It's cold, so I'll close the door, okay?
examples.ja: 寒いから、ドア閉めるね！

examples.en: This shop is closing down.
examples.ja: この店、閉めることになったんだ。

examples.en: If you don't close the lid properly, bugs might get in!
examples.ja: ちゃんとフタを閉めておかないと、虫が入るかもしれないよ！

examples.en: I hate when my husband twists the caps back on plastic bottles really tightly.
examples.ja: 旦那がペットボトルのキャップを閉める時、キツく締めすぎるのが嫌です。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>closed</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to close something</vocabulary>.

閉める primarily means <vocabulary>to shut something</vocabulary> in a physical sense (often with a sliding or twisting motion), like when you close doors, windows, curtains, faucets, and so on. Additionally, it can also be used for closing shops, either for the day or permanently.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you want <vocabulary>to close something</vocabulary>, use a <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Sheep are famously good closers. Doors, windows, curtains, you name it. Sure, they'll bleat on and on about how they're not your personal closer, they have their own doors to close, and bah bah blah, but they secretly love having the chance <vocabulary>to shut something</vocabulary> for you.

examples.en: There is a spider on the ceiling!
examples.ja: 天井にクモがいる！

examples.en: I want to hang this planter from the ceiling.
examples.ja: このプランター、天井からつるしたいんだ。

examples.en: It seems like that day was the ceiling for the stock market.
examples.ja: どうやらあの日が相場の天井だったようだね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>well</kanji> is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a <vocabulary>ceiling</vocabulary>. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 井, so we've got a mnemonic to help you out with that. Just note that the on'yomi for 井 isn't actually じょう, but rather しょう, it just ends up getting rendaku'd here!

Fixing up <vocabulary>ceilings</vocabulary> is a tricky task, but you've got just the man for it: <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう). Your local farmhand that does it all, nothing is too tricky or out of reach for him, you're starting to think that this man can do just about anything. What a handy person to have around.

examples.en: My father is a car dealer.
examples.ja: 私の父は自動車のディーラーです。

examples.en: Nowadays, every car manufacturer is putting effort into developing electric vehicles.
examples.ja: 今はどの自動車メーカーも、電気自動車の開発に力を入れています。

examples.en: I want to buy a new car, but which one do you recommend?
examples.ja: 新しい自動車を買いたいんですが、どれがおすすめですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 自動 is <vocabulary>automatic</vocabulary>. So what is an automatic <kanji>car</kanji>? That is an <vocabulary>automobile</vocabulary>, or simply a <vocabulary>car</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 自動 and the kanji 車's readings, combined.

examples.en: I can't buy the Japanese textbook because it's too expensive.
examples.ja: その日本語の教科書は高すぎて買えません。

examples.en: Please don't illegally download textbooks from the web; instead, buy them properly.
examples.ja: 教科書はウェブから不正ダウンロードしないで、ちゃんと買ってくださいね。

examples.en: We were told that tomorrow, I have to bring my math drills and Japanese textbooks.
examples.ja: 明日、計算ドリルと国語の教科書を持って行かなきゃいけないんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: The thing you use to <kanji>teach</kanji> a <kanji>course</kanji> with <kanji>writing</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>textbook</vocabulary>. It's a book of writings you use to teach your course!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He hit his face hard on the asphalt.
examples.ja: 彼はアスファルトに顔面を強打した。

examples.en: During gym class, I got hit square in the face with a basketball.
examples.ja: 体育の時間、顔面に思いっきりバスケットボールが当たったんです。

examples.en: It appears that there's a slight paralysis in your facial area.
examples.ja: どうやら顔面に少しマヒが出ているようですね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>face</kanji> of a <kanji>face</kanji> is a face, but more specifically the <vocabulary>face of a person</vocabulary>. Probably because the most face-like thing you can ever have is a human's face... at least in our eyes (by "our" I mean the human race's eyes, because I am totally with you guys on that one).
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 顔 isn't the one you learned with the kanji. But, we're going to learn that reading right now.

The worst thing that can happen to a face is if a face disappears. If it becomes totally <reading>gone</reading> (がん). A man that is walking up to you with no face, is a man with a gone face. Those men are men who are a part of the <reading>gone men</reading> (がんめん). Faces, totally gone!

examples.en: Isn't that too sudden, by any measure?
examples.ja: それはいくら何でも急すぎない？

examples.en: It was such sudden news that she was surprised.
examples.ja: それはとても急な知らせだったので、彼女はビックリしました。

examples.en: I took on an urgent job, so I will be home around nine o'clock today.
examples.ja: 急な仕事を引き受けちゃったので、今日の帰りは九時くらいになります。

meaning_mnemonic: This takes its meaning from the <kanji>sudden</kanji> part of the kanji, meaning it's <vocabulary>sudden</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>urgent</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>emergency</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Even yakuza can come to the zoo.
examples.ja: ヤクザだって動物園に来ることもあるさ。

examples.en: The flamingos looked so beautiful when I saw them up close at a zoological garden.
examples.ja: 動物園で間近で見たフラミンゴは、とてもきれいでした。

examples.en: Many koalas congenitally carry a virus called the koala retrovirus, and when they experience stress, it can lead to fatal consequences. Therefore, in zoos, please be careful not to use camera flashes or raise your voice excessively.
examples.ja: 多くのコアラはコアラレトロウィルスというウイルスを先天的に保持しており、ストレスなどを受けると、死につながることがあります。ですので、動物園では、カメラのフラッシュや大声を出すなどしないよう、十分気をつけてください。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 動物 means animal? Well when you add <kanji>park</kanji> it becomes a <vocabulary>zoo</vocabulary>. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'm planning to go to dinner with him on our anniversary.
examples.ja: 記念日には、彼とディナーに行く予定です。

examples.en: I'm currently reading "Salad Anniversary."
examples.ja: 今は『サラダ記念日』を読んでいます。

examples.en: Today is the anniversary of the broadcast debut of "WaniKani-sama."
examples.ja: 今日は『ワニカニ様』の放送開始記念日です。

meaning_mnemonic:
You should <kanji>write down</kanji> all your <kanji>thoughts</kanji> on this <kanji>day</kanji>, because it's not just any day — it's an <vocabulary>anniversary</vocabulary>!

Wondering how 記念日 differs from 周年? 周年 is usually for a numbered anniversary, like 十周年 (10th anniversary), whereas 記念日 refers to the specific date on which a memorable event took place in the past.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi for the first two and kun'yomi for the last one. That being said, all of the readings for all of the kanji are the readings you've learned already, so you should be able to read this word too. Just watch out because ひ is rendaku'd into び.

examples.en: Koichi is a really cheerful boy.
examples.ja: コウイチ君は本当に陽気な男の子ですね。

examples.en: A day with warm weather like today makes me want to have a picnic.
examples.ja: 今日みたいに温かい陽気の日にはピクニックがしたくなりますね。

examples.en: My family is poor but jovial.
examples.ja: うちの家族は貧乏だが陽気だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you have a <kanji>sunshine</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji>, you're probably a really <vocabulary>cheerful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>jovial</vocabulary> person. 

陽気 can also refer to <vocabulary>warm weather</vocabulary>. (Technically it refers to weather or climate in general, but these days people associate it with warm, sunny weather because of its kanji.)
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is very convenient and can be used in many situations!
examples.ja: これ、色んな場面で活用できてすごく便利ですよ！

examples.en: This phrase is often used in business situations.
examples.ja: このフレーズは、ビジネスの場面でよく使います。

examples.en: I cried during the last scene.
examples.ja: 最後の場面で泣いてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: Everything on a <kanji>location</kanji>'s <kanji>surface</kanji> is really just a part of the <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary> before you. This is the kind of scene that would be set in a novel. It's the <vocabulary>setting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

A <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary> where everyone says "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば) isn't very common… Unless you're reading a novel where all the characters are sheep! You find this novel's animal-centric <vocabulary>setting</vocabulary> to be pretty unique and interesting, but, honestly, all the baaing makes the dialogue a little hard to follow.

examples.en: I don't quite understand how to use the dictionary, could you please teach me?
examples.ja: 辞典の使い方がよく分からないんですが、教えてもらえませんか？

examples.en: If you're looking for a Japanese dictionary, it's on my desk.
examples.ja: 日本語辞典なら、私のデスクの上にありますよ。

examples.en: An electronic dictionary has various dictionaries in it.
examples.ja: 電子辞書には色んな辞典が入っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You need to know the <kanji>word</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji>s of the language you're learning, don't you? Then you need a good <vocabulary>dictionary</vocabulary> that can explain its <vocabulary>lexicon</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ll get good luck with this good luck charm.
examples.ja: 幸運になるおまじないよ。

examples.en: He was fortunate enough to have won the lottery and received a prize of one hundred million yen.
examples.ja: 彼は幸運にも宝くじに当たり、賞金一億円を手に入れました。

examples.en: I'm guessing that the meaning of Koichi's name is the "most lucky" person. What do you think?
examples.ja: コウイチの名前の意味は、一番幸運な人っていう意味なんじゃないかと思ってるんだけど、どう思う？

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>carry</kanji> <kanji>happiness</kanji> with you, you look at the good side of everything and end up having really <vocabulary>good luck</vocabulary>. Someone who carries happiness will be really lucky in life.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My heart breaks when you say that.
examples.ja: そんなことを言われると、心が折れるよ。

examples.en: I broke my finger while playing volleyball.
examples.ja: バレーボールをしてる時に、指の骨が折れてしまいました。

examples.en: Oh, my God, it's terrible. The tulip has snapped off at the base!
examples.ja: ええっ、ひどい。チューリップ、根元からポッキリ折れてる！

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned how 折る means "to fold something" or "to break something". This is the intransitive version of that, which just means it has no object. You just folded something too far, and now it's starting <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 折る, so you should know this one too!

examples.en: Our house is right next to the house with a brown gate.
examples.ja: 私たちの家は、茶色い門のある家のすぐとなりです。

examples.en: If you pass under the big gate, you will see the temple.
examples.ja: あそこの大きい門をくぐるとお寺が見えるよ。

examples.en: The gate is locked.
examples.ja: 門にはカギがかかっているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I go to Costco to buy groceries on the weekend.
examples.ja: 週末には食料品を買いにコストコに行きます。

examples.en: Before going grocery shopping, I always make a shopping list.
examples.ja: 食料品を買いに行く前に、いつも買い出しリストを作ります。

examples.en: Could you tell me where the grocery section is?
examples.ja: 食料品売場はどこにありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Product</kanji>s you're paying a <kanji>fee</kanji> to <kanji>eat</kanji> later are your <vocabulary>groceries</vocabulary>. Buy them now, eat them later, yum!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This area doesn’t have bad public safety, but that area does.
examples.ja: この辺りは治安も悪くないけど、あの辺りは治安が良くないからね。

examples.en: If Japan's birthrate continues to decline, public safety will worsen.
examples.ja: このまま日本の少子化が進むと、治安も悪化するでしょう。

examples.en: I'm actually Superman and I'm the one who keeps the peace around here.
examples.ja: 俺は実はスーパーマンなんだ。この辺りの治安を守っているのはこの俺様なんだぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: If your people can <kanji>relax</kanji> because you <kanji>rule</kanji> over them so well, there is <vocabulary>public order</vocabulary>. You don't want the people you rule being upset or stressed out, you want <vocabulary>public safety</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>public peace</vocabulary> for all!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How would you like to pay?
examples.ja: お支払い方法はどうなさいますか？

examples.en: Please make payments by card.
examples.ja: 支払いはカードでお願いします。

examples.en: Thank goodness, now I can pay my bills!
examples.ja: よかったー、これで支払いができる！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>pay</kanji> that <kanji>support</kanji>s you is made in <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary>s. Whether you make payments to keep your house or your car, or you get payments from your boss, they keep you going.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 支 and the kun'yomi reading of 払. You've learned them both, so you know this too!

examples.en: I'm looking for a tag to put on my suitcase.
examples.ja: 旅行カバンに付ける荷札をさがしています。

examples.en: Please tell me how to write a package label.
examples.ja: 荷札の書き方を教えてください。

examples.en: The label is coming off from the parcel.
examples.ja: そのパッケージ、荷札がはがれてるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>luggage</kanji> <kanji>tag</kanji> is a <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> you put on luggage. It's also a <vocabulary>label</vocabulary> you can put on a package before you send it, like a <vocabulary>shipping label</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too.

examples.en: Wasn't the school trip scheduled for next week?
examples.ja: 遠足って来週だったよね？

examples.en: My kid just got back from the school trip a little while ago. Seems like they had a blast!
examples.ja: うちの子、さっき遠足から帰ってきたよ。めっちゃ楽しかったみたい！

examples.en: We went on a school trip to the zoo.
examples.ja: 学校の遠足で、動物園に行きました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Far</kanji> <kanji>feet</kanji> are feet that have gone on long <vocabulary>excursions</vocabulary>. These feet have been on some <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary>s, man. They've seen some things.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We're making sure to release the small mantis shrimps back into the sea.
examples.ja: 小さいシャコは海に帰すようにしています。

examples.en: I sent my driver home a little early today.
examples.ja: 今日は少し早く運転手を帰した。

examples.en: They won't send you home unless you finish all of the work.
examples.ja: 作業が全部終わらないと帰してもらえないよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The hiragana ends with an う sound, so you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. You send someone back. You send them home. And tell them to never come near you again. So this means <vocabulary>to send someone back</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to send someone home</vocabulary>.

In fact, most verbs ending in す are transitive. To help you remember that, think of <reading>su</reading>ing (す) someone to make sure they go home!
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Yay! But since this word has a pair verb, let's think of a way to remember the ending:

What's the most surefire way to send someone home? Threaten to <reading>sue</reading> (す) them if they don't!

examples.en: Wow, this bread is so fluffy, isn't it!
examples.ja: うわー、このパン、ふわふわだね！

examples.en: Isn't it cute to see jellyfish floating in the sea?
examples.ja: クラゲが海でふわふわ泳いでるのって、かわいくない？

examples.en: I’m kind of light-headed.
examples.ja: なんか頭がふわふわする。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Who are who are</reading> (ふわふわ) <vocabulary>fluffy</vocabulary>? I’m thinking puppies, but ask yourself, "who are the fluffiest creatures I know?"

This is an オノマトペ meaning fluffy, like a puppy, a cloud, or a cotton ball. It can also describe the movement of a dandelion puffball or a jellyfish, <vocabulary>floating lightly</vocabulary> in the air or the water. And if you’re <vocabulary>feeling lightheaded</vocabulary>, that’s called ふわふわ too. Basically, anything with light or fluffy vibe!

examples.en: Stress is causing the disease to worsen quickly.
examples.ja: ストレスのせいで、病気の悪化が早い。

examples.en: Last night, my flu suddenly got worse.
examples.ja: 昨日の夜、インフルエンザが一気に悪化した。

examples.en: In recent times, there has been a notable decline in the overall safety of this neighborhood.
examples.ja: 最近この辺りは治安がかなり悪化している。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> is exactly what it sounds like: <vocabulary>deterioration</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>getting worse</vocabulary> .
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The on'yomi readings of the kanji are あく and か, but here they become あっか, to make the word easier to pronounce. Try and say it out loud to see if you agree.

examples.en: I'll contact the manufacturer.
examples.ja: メーカーに問い合わせるよ。

examples.en: Why don't you try sending an inquiry by email?
examples.ja: メールで問い合わせてみたら？

examples.en: I wanted to inquire in advance, but I couldn't get through on the phone.
examples.ja: 事前に問い合わせたかったんだけど、電話がつながらなかったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 問う means "to question something" and 合わせる means "to join together"? If you're joining your questions together, you're probably trying to <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary> about something. Inquiring is much more involved than plain old asking, after all.

問い合わせる is a phrase you can use when contacting a business or government office to request information or resolve an issue. It's a bit formal, but in an everyday business-speak kind of way, and it doesn't have the philosophical or weighty tone that 問う does.
reading_mnemonic:
You probably know how to read 問う and 合わせる already. 問う is still pretty new though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the 問 part:

You love <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary> with your <reading>toe</reading>s (と). Whenever you fill out one of those online forms to contact customer support with an inquiry, you do all your typing with your toes. They don't know you're making this inquiry with your toes — but you do, and it makes you chuckle.

examples.en: Here's a quick and easy recipe where all you need to do is dip them in the sauce and microwave them.
examples.ja: ソースにつけてレンジでチンするだけのお手軽レシピです。

examples.en: We have created an application that makes it easy to collect "WaniKani Cards".
examples.ja: 「ワニカニカード」が手軽にコレクションできるアプリを作りました。

examples.en: Let's move our bodies with easy exercises.
examples.ja: 手軽にできるエクササイズで体を動かしましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>hand</kanji>s are <kanji>light</kanji> because it was a <vocabulary>simple and easy</vocabulary> task, so you didn't get your hands full. This word describes something that's hassle-free and doesn't take much effort, time, or sometimes cost to do.
reading_mnemonic: Both kanji use kun'yomi readings in this word, which you've already learned. Just make sure you rendaku the 軽.

examples.en: If communication isn't done well, some issues might arise.
examples.ja: コミュニケーションが上手くできていないと、トラブルが生じるかもしれません。

examples.en: From there, many problems emerged.
examples.ja: そこから多くの問題が生じました。

examples.en: Due to system updates, it will be necessary to temporarily halt the system.
examples.ja: システムのアップデートにより一時的にシステムを止める必要が生じます。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 生まれる means "to be born"? This word is similar, but it's used for when non-living things are "born". So as an intransitive verb, this means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to arise</vocabulary>. When used transitively, it means <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. You'll probably encounter the intransitive use much more, though.
reading_mnemonic:
You'd think this would use kun'yomi, but it actually doesn't! Like other verbs ending in じる, this takes the on'yomi reading of the kanji. 生 has two of those, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

If you wanted anything <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary> in medieval Japan, you needed to talk to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun. You always needed the Shougun's help <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. Without the Shougun, nothing would ever happen!

examples.en: I found a ramen restaurant that has a line.
examples.ja: 行列のできるラーメン屋を見つけた。

examples.en: Oh, a line of ants!
examples.ja: あ、アリの行列だ！

examples.en: I lined up in a queue at midnight to buy concert tickets.
examples.ja: コンサートのチケットを買うために、夜中から行列にならびました。

examples.en: I learned about matrices today in math class.
examples.ja: 今日は数学のクラスで行列について学びました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know the two words that make up this word, 行 and 列, and they both have similar meanings: a line and a row. Put them together and you have a <vocabulary>line</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>queue</vocabulary>.

This usually means a line of people waiting for their turn, for example to enter a restaurant. It can be also used for a line that marches, like a line in a parade. In a mathematics context, it can refer to a <vocabulary>matrix</vocabulary>, which makes sense because they're lines and rows of numbers and stuff.
reading_mnemonic: This word takes the readings of the two words that make it up, so you should be lining up to read it!

examples.en: It is dangerous to stack so many plates.
examples.ja: そんなにお皿を重ねると危ないですよ。

examples.en: The princess became more and more beautiful as she grew older.
examples.ja: プリンセスは、年を重ねるごとに美しくなっていきました。

examples.en: Isn't it a waste of time to have a bunch of discussions about things that don't have answers?
examples.ja: 答えのないことにディスカッションを重ねるのってムダじゃないですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
You've got lots of <kanji>heavy</kanji> things, so the only logical thing is <vocabulary>to stack</vocabulary> them all up. 

Besides heavy physical things, you can also use this word when you're going <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary> things like experience, practice, or years on your back.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

All the things you've <vocabulary>stack</vocabulary>ed up were in preparation for your new <reading>casa</reading> (かさ). With everything inside boxes and neatly piled up, you're finally ready to move into your new casa. Hooray!

examples.en: Hey, isn't that former Prime Minister Mori?
examples.ja: あれ、森元首相じゃない？

examples.en: What do you think about the Prime Minister's remarks yesterday?
examples.ja: 昨日の首相の発言について、どう思いますか？

examples.en: This is where the Prime Minister can really show off their leadership, isn't it?
examples.ja: これは首相のリーダーシップの見せ所ですね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>neck</kanji> <kanji>minister</kanji>? This meaning <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary> makes sense if you think about the neck being the most important part of the body, kind of like the head!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. It also uses a reading for 相 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The first <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary>s of Japan were actually the <reading>sho</reading>guns (しょう)… kind of.

examples.en: Please come again when the new greenery is out.
examples.ja: 新緑の時期にまた来てくださいね。

examples.en: April and May are definitely the months when the new foliage is most beautiful.
examples.ja: 新緑が一番きれいなのはやっぱり四月と五月ですよ。

examples.en: I feel like my eyesight improved just from gazing at the mountains covered in new green leaves.
examples.ja: 新緑の山をずーっと見てたら目が良くなった気がするんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
What's <kanji>new</kanji> and <kanji>green</kanji>? That'd be the <vocabulary>new greenery</vocabulary> you see on trees and other plants every year!

新緑 refers to <vocabulary>new foliage</vocabulary> — fresh green leaves of late spring and early summer, just after they've fully emerged. In Japan, it's seen as a symbol of that time of year, so it often carries a slightly poetic nuance.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've seen them before (remember the りょく reading from 緑茶?), so you should be good to go here.
